title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement andrewbruce.himni@gmail.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. title: Defogging Transparency in Coverage Files
text: Next ’ll download one --network (OON) files, also known “allowed amounts” files. results , can filter rate_type column out_of_network make sure remove duplicate URLs {dplyr}’s distinct() function:   Next, plug URL object defog_oon() function retrieve file:  , ’ve limited output first ten rows demonstration purposes, gives good idea OON file contains. Next, ’ll retrieve -network file.
code: centene_oon_CA <- centene_toc |>    dplyr::filter(rate_type == "out_of_network") |>    dplyr::select(location) |>    dplyr::distinct() |>    tibble::deframe() #> [1] "http://centene.com/content/dam/centene/Centene%20Corporate/json/DOCUMENT/2022-06-29_centene-management-company-llc_ambetter-ca_allowed-amounts.json" centene_oon_CA_file <- defog_oon(centene_oon_CA) |>                         dplyr::slice_head(n = 10)

title: Defogging Transparency in Coverage Files
text: workflow -network (INN) file much , though output different, thus need different function. time, filter rate_type column in_network, making sure remove duplicate URLs:   plug URL object defog_inn() function:   output shows first ten rows 141,580 total. , without doubt, embarassment riches us healthcare data analytics. However, absent data points enable us expand analysis even . NPPES NPI Registry API comes handy.
code: centene_inn_CA <- centene_toc |>    dplyr::filter(rate_type == "in_network") |>    dplyr::select(location) |>    dplyr::distinct() |>    tibble::deframe() #> [1] "http://centene.com/content/dam/centene/Centene%20Corporate/json/DOCUMENT/2022-06-29_centene-management-company-llc_ambetter-ca_in-network.json" centene_inn_CA_file <- defog_inn(centene_inn_CA) |>                         dplyr::slice_head(n = 10)

title: Defogging Transparency in Coverage Files
text: Using NPPES Registry Search, can retrieve data provider’s taxonomy, credentials, gender, NPI type, payer-specific identifiers, etc. First, need isolate distinct NPIs OON INN results . five distinct NPIs --network file:   10 distinct NPIs -network file:   Next, pipe {defogger}’s NPPES search function, defog_npi(), via {purrr}’s map_dfr():   gives us two responses NPPES API, can unpack defog_npi_wide() function:    can join two pairs data frames analysis:     joins give us data frames following 68 columns:   Please see Big Data: dm, arrow & duckdb vignette example much -depth analysis.
code: # OON file centene_oon_npi <- centene_oon_CA_file |>                     dplyr::distinct(npi) |>                     unlist(use.names = FALSE) #> [1] "1104868124" "1366964330" "1760041487" "1902967557" "1710065933" # INN file centene_inn_npi <- centene_inn_CA_file |>                     dplyr::distinct(npi) |>                     unlist(use.names = FALSE) #>  [1] "1063050748" "1114499340" "1801314687" "1477217966" "1730531328" #>  [6] "1578813234" "1912103383" "1356852495" "1043304702" "1730294547" # OON file NPIs centene_oon_npi_resp <- centene_oon_npi |>                          purrr::map_dfr(defog_npi) #> # A tibble: 5 × 4 #>   search     datetime            outcome data_lists    #>   <chr>      <dttm>              <chr>   <list>        #> 1 1104868124 2022-09-02 06:06:35 results <df [1 × 11]> #> 2 1366964330 2022-09-02 06:06:37 results <df [1 × 11]> #> 3 1760041487 2022-09-02 06:06:40 results <df [1 × 11]> #> 4 1902967557 2022-09-02 06:06:42 results <df [1 × 11]> #> 5 1710065933 2022-09-02 06:06:44 results <df [1 × 11]> # INN file NPIs centene_inn_npi_resp <- centene_inn_npi |>                          purrr::map_dfr(defog_npi) #> # A tibble: 10 × 4 #>    search     datetime            outcome data_lists    #>    <chr>      <dttm>              <chr>   <list>        #>  1 1063050748 2022-09-02 06:06:46 results <df [1 × 11]> #>  2 1114499340 2022-09-02 06:06:48 results <df [1 × 11]> #>  3 1801314687 2022-09-02 06:06:51 results <df [1 × 11]> #>  4 1477217966 2022-09-02 06:06:53 results <df [1 × 11]> #>  5 1730531328 2022-09-02 06:06:55 results <df [1 × 11]> #>  6 1578813234 2022-09-02 06:06:57 results <df [1 × 11]> #>  7 1912103383 2022-09-02 06:06:59 results <df [1 × 11]> #>  8 1356852495 2022-09-02 06:07:02 results <df [1 × 11]> #>  9 1043304702 2022-09-02 06:07:04 results <df [1 × 11]> #> 10 1730294547 2022-09-02 06:07:06 results <df [1 × 11]> # OON file response centene_oon_npi_result <- centene_oon_npi_resp |>                            dplyr::group_split(search) |>                            purrr::map_dfr(defog_npi_wide) # INN file response centene_inn_npi_result <- centene_inn_npi_resp |>                            dplyr::group_split(search) |>                            purrr::map_dfr(defog_npi_wide) # OON join centene_oon_npi_join <- dplyr::full_join(centene_oon_CA_file,                                           centene_oon_npi_result,                                           by = "npi") #> # A tibble: 1,320 × 69 #>    name    billi…¹ billi…² billi…³ descr…⁴ ein   servi…⁵ billi…⁶ allow…⁷ bille…⁸ #>    <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   <chr> <chr>   <chr>     <dbl>   <dbl> #>  1 ANES U… CPT     2022    00813   ANESTH… 3301… 24      profes…   1568     4655 #>  2 ANES U… CPT     2022    00813   ANESTH… 3301… 24      profes…   1568     4655 #>  3 NFCT D… HCPCS   2022    0202U   NFCT D… 8220… 20      profes…   9586.   33925 #>  4 NFCT D… HCPCS   2022    0202U   NFCT D… 8220… 20      profes…   9586.   33925 #>  5 ANTIBO… HCPCS   2022    0224U   ANTB S… 4641… 11      profes…   1475.   10500 #>  6 ANTIBO… HCPCS   2022    0224U   ANTB S… 4641… 11      profes…   1475.   10500 #>  7 ANTIBO… HCPCS   2022    0224U   ANTB S… 4641… 11      profes…   1475.   10500 #>  8 ANTIBO… HCPCS   2022    0224U   ANTB S… 4641… 11      profes…   1475.   10500 #>  9 ANTIBO… HCPCS   2022    0224U   ANTB S… 4641… 11      profes…   1475.   10500 #> 10 ANTIBO… HCPCS   2022    0224U   ANTB S… 4641… 11      profes…   1475.   10500 #> # … with 1,310 more rows, 59 more variables: npi <chr>, location <chr>, #> name_prefix <chr>, country_abb <chr>, country_name <chr>, #> #   address_purpose <chr>, address_type <chr>, address_1 <chr>, #> #   address_2 <chr>, city <chr>, state_abb <chr>, postal_code <chr>, … # INN join centene_inn_npi_join <- dplyr::full_join(centene_inn_CA_file,                                           centene_inn_npi_result,                                           by = "npi") #> # A tibble: 42 × 69 #>    negot…¹ name  billi…² billi…³ billi…⁴ descr…⁵ negot…⁶ negot…⁷ expir…⁸ servi…⁹ #>    <chr>   <chr> <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   <chr>     <dbl> <chr>   <chr>   #>  1 ffs STRAPP… negoti…    27.0 9999-1… 11      #>  4 ffs     STRA… CPT     2022    29240   STRAPP… negoti…    27.0 9999-1… 11      #>  5 ffs     STRA… CPT     2022    29240   STRAPP… negoti…    27.0 9999-1… title: Transparency in Coverage Guide
text: October 29, 2020, HHS Departments Labor Treasury finalized Transparency Coverage (TiC) Final Rule (CMS-9115-F) requiring health plans issuers individual group commercial markets disclose cost-sharing estimates additional content enrollees upon request, publicly post negotiated -network provider rates, historical --network allowed amounts billed charges, drug pricing information, including negotiated rates historical net prices. final rule latest number Administration efforts increase price transparency healthcare services order empower consumers make informed decisions foster price competition healthcare market. Beyond consumer empowerment, however, HHS clearly articulates principle focus counteracting price distortions driving prices commercial market. Therefore, just Hospital Price Transparency Final Rule, published November 2019 set take effect January 2021, faced strong stakeholder opposition subject legal challenge, final rule may likely challenged health plans industry stakeholders. Indeed, HHS clearly anticipates rule face legal challenges included severability clauses part rule even portion rule challenged successfully, provisions rule might continue survive.

title: Transparency in Coverage Guide
text: machine-readable file (MRF) defined digital representation data information file can imported read computer system processing without human intervention, ensuring semantic meaning lost. files CMS defined format (JSON) meant member-friendly search rates, benefits, cost sharing. table contents approved CMS schema approach combines -network rate files references locations (URLs) appropriate files can downloaded. Transparency Coverage Rule requires health insurers group health plans, including self-funded clients, provide cost-sharing data consumers via MRFs. must published publicly available site based enforcement date July 1, 2022 plan years beginning Jan. 1, 2022. files provide pricing data covered items services based -network negotiated payment rates historical --network allowed amounts. third machine-readable file prescription drug rates historical costs delayed pending guidance. Information files must updated published monthly. machine-readable files must available internet website free charge. user required establish user account, password, credentials require user submit personal identifying information name, email address, telephone number. Files required fewer 20 claims service provider.  · Files requirements regarding font size, accessibility, security settings. · Files may posted third party site. · Files may PDF Excel.

text: JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) lightweight data-interchange format. easy humans read write. easy machines parse generate. based subset JavaScript Programming Language Standard ECMA-262 3rd Edition - December 1999. JSON text format completely language independent uses conventions familiar programmers C-family languages, including C, C++, C#, Java, JavaScript, Perl, Python, many others. properties make JSON ideal data-interchange language. JSON built two structures: collection name/value pairs. various languages, realized object, record, struct, dictionary, hash table, keyed list, associative array. ordered list values. languages, realized array, vector, list, sequence. universal data structures. Virtually modern programming languages support one form another. makes sense data format interchangeable programming languages also based structures.

title: Streamlined Workflow for Transparency in Coverage (TiC) Data Analysis
text: Health plan price transparency helps consumers know cost covered item service receiving care. Beginning July 1, 2022, group health plans issuers group individual health insurance begin posting pricing information covered items services. pricing information can used third parties, researchers app developers help consumers better understand costs associated health care. requirements go effect starting January 1, 2023, January 1, 2024 provide additional access pricing information enhance consumers’ ability shop health care best meet needs.1  Transparency Coverage Final Rule2 requires group health plans issuers group individual health insurance disclose pricing information form machine-readable files containing following sets costs items services:  -Network Rate File: Rates covered items services plan issuer -network providers.  Allowed Amount File: Allowed amounts , billed charges , --network providers.  CMS.gov: data contained machine-readable files plans issuers, third party developers able create much advanced accurate price transparency tools. tools help inform consumers, well broader public, patterns health care costs offer immense opportunities innovation. Making price transparency information publicly available strengthens work health care stakeholders help provide care promote access care consumers, otherwise aim protect consumers interests health care system. entities include researchers, regulators, lawmakers, patient consumer advocates, businesses provide consumer support tools services. key aspect Transparency Coverage make health care pricing information accessible useful consumers making information available persons entities requisite experience expertise assist individual consumers health care purchasers make informed health care decisions. information pricing, health care stakeholders can better fulfill unique roles play improve America’s health care system consumers. instance, pricing information, researchers better assess cost-effectiveness various treatments; state regulators better review issuers’ proposed rate increases; patient advocates better help guide patients care plans; employers adopt incentives consumers choose cost-effective care; entrepreneurs develop tools help doctors better engage patients.
